newsitem.title: USA: Volt Information Q4 shr $1.04 vs $0.82.
newsitem.headline: Volt Information Q4 shr $1.04 vs $0.82.

text.p: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
(Dollars in thousands, except per share data)
redemption of debt, net of income
of debt, net of income taxes (0.01) --
Number of shares used in computation 10,068,939 9,656,131
(Dollars in thousands, except per share data)
redemption of debt, net of income
of debt, net of income taxes (0.01) (0.01)
Number of shares used in computation 9,866,443 9,634,334

Note A -- On January 29, 1996, the company completed the merger of Autologic with Information International Inc, resulting in the formation of a new publicly traded company, Autologic Information International, Inc. (Nasdaq: AIII). As a result of the merger transaction, Volt owns 59 percent of AIII and realized a first quarter pre-tax gain of $3,666,000 ($2,371,000, net of taxes, or $0.24 per share), net of expenses, on the partial sale of Autologic.

Note B -- As a result an Oct 1996 Internal Revenue Service examination of the company's tax returns for fiscal years 1989 through 1993, $1.4 million ($0.14 per share) and $723,000 ($443,000, net of taxes, or $0.04 per share) were included as a tax benefit and interest income, respectively, for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended November 1, 1996 in respect of items which were previously reserved.

Note C -- The results for the fiscal year ended November 1, 1996 included first and second quarter gains aggregating $2,625,000 ($1,600,000, net of taxes, or $0.16 per share), as a result of an agreement to pay an insurance premium.

Note D -- The extraordinary charge to earnings in fiscal 1996 was the result of the early redemption, in September 1996, at par, of the remaining $22,855,000 face value of the company's 12.375 percent Subordinated Debentures.
The charge was due to the related issuance costs, and is net of an income tax benefit of $55,000.
In fiscal 1995, the company redeemed $10,000,000 of debentures, at par. The charge, due to the related issuance costs, was net of an income tax benefit of $42,000.
